etymologies: late 19th century; earliest use found in Sydney Vines (1849–1934), botanist. From auto- + -oecious, in sense 1 after German autoecisch

definitions: Of parasitic fungi (especially rusts and smuts): inhabiting the same host throughout their life.
Of a bryophyte or its inflorescence: having both male and female sexual organs (antheridia and archegonia), but on separate shoots; also called autoicous.
